If one sends food to them, even if it is just a spoonful of salt or a handful of grass leaves, and they eat it in the assembly, there is no offense.
Or if the donor says:
I will give food to anyone who comes in.
Or if the donor builds a separate house and gives it, saying:

This is also without fault.
Moreover, there is no offense for the first offender, the rest as explained above.
The training rule on eating at improper times, the thirty-seventh. The Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in Jeta's Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, MahÄmaudgalyÄyana gave the going forth and full ordination to the group of seventeen.

The behavior of women is led by greed and love. At that time, there were many young women who saw the seventeen young bhiká¹£us holding their bowls and begging for food. They all beat their chests with their hands and said:
These bhiká¹£us, from childhood to adulthood, have been raised by their mothers without any gratitude. They have left home to become monks. What fruits and benefits are there?
Why not fill their mouths with dirt and abandon them in a pit after they are born?
At that time, the seventeen bhiká¹£us heard these words and felt ashamed. They said to each other:

They all returned to the temple, stopped eating, and stayed there. Until their food supply was exhausted, they practiced various wholesome activities. When their food supply was exhausted, they all lay down.

You seventeen people, eating others' food, is your belly not also others'?
How can you lie down without cultivating wholesome practices after eating to the full?
They said:
Venerable One!
Who ate to the full?
He replied:
It is you all.
Then the seventeen people immediately reported the matter to Upananda. When he heard it, he left in silence.
At that time, there were some laypeople who were playing and enjoying themselves in the garden, and the day had already passed noon.
Then the seventeen people also went to the garden and in front of the crowd, they rubbed their bellies and recited a verse, saying:
The Buddha speaks beautiful and wonderful words that fill the world;
Within suffering, there is none greater than hunger. These words are the most true.
When the people saw this, they asked:
Noble ones!
Do you wish to eat?
They replied:
We wish to.

The people brought good food and gave it to them, and they all ate until they were full. After they were full, they each returned to their original places and recited and practiced in high voices, following each other in pairs.
At that time, Upananda heard the sound of recitation and practice, came to their place and asked:
Why are you, the group of seventeen, now making energetic progress and reciting and practicing in high voices, twice as much as usual?
The group of seventeen replied:
Have you not heard the World-Honored One say:
'If the mind is joyful, one can expound the meaning of the Dharma.'
Upananda said:

They replied:
In the garden, we got to eat until we were full.
Upananda said:
Just now, I asked you if you were all hungry, why do you now say you are full?
Could it be that you ate at the wrong time?
They replied:ğŸ”½Venerable Upasena, we did not eat at the wrong time.
Not eating after noon, how could I let hunger take my life?
The monks of few desires heard this and gave rise to disgust and contempt, saying:

They took this matter and reported it in detail to the World-Honored One.
The World-Honored One then gathered the assembly of bhiká¹£us and asked about the causes and conditions, explaining in detail as above, up to:
How can a bhiká¹£u eat at the wrong time?
The World-Honored One reprimanded him in various ways and told the bhiká¹£us:
For the sake of the ten benefits, I establish the training rule that should be said like this:
If a bhiká¹£u eats at the wrong time, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
If a bhiká¹£u means the group of seventeen, the rest of the meaning is the same as above.
As for the wrong time, there are two kinds:
One is after noon, the other is before dawn, the offense is concluded as above.
What are the circumstances of the offense in this case?

If a bhiká¹£u, not knowing it is the wrong time, has the thought of the wrong time or is unsure of it, and eats, he commits an offense entailing confession.ğŸ”½If it is the right time, but he has the thought of the wrong time or is unsure of it, and eats, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If it is the right time, and he perceives it as such, and it is the wrong time, and he perceives it as such, there is no offense.
There is no offense if it is the first offense; the rest is as above.
The training rule on eating food that has been touched, the thirty-eighth. The Buddha was staying at Jetavana, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸adaâ€™s Park, near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time, Venerable Kolita always had this rule: every morning he put on his robes, took his bowl, and entered the village to go on sequential almsround. After getting the food, he ate the wet rice that day, and he dried the dry rice and put it in a pot.
If they encounter wind, cold, overcast, or rainy weather, they would soak the warm water to use as food.
After eating to their satisfaction, they would experience the subtle bliss of meditative concentration, liberation, samÄdhi, and samÄpatti.

It is the constant practice of the Buddhas to abide in the world, and from time to time they go to the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, human realms, and heavenly realms, as well as to mountains, forests, rivers, and streams where corpses are left, or to the abodes of bhiká¹£us, to observe the causes and conditions there and to observe the abodes.
At that time, the World-Honored One went to the dwelling place of the Venerable Kolita and saw that dried rice was being sunned. He said to Ä€nanda:
Whose dried rice is being sunned now?
At that time, Ä€nanda told in detail about Kolita's begging for food, and how he experienced subtle bliss.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
Is there any bhiká¹£u who eats food that has been touched by others?
Ä€nanda said to the Buddha:
There is.
The World-Honored One gathered the assembly and reprimanded them in various ways, criticizing their lack of tranquility and praising the practice of contentment. He told the bhiká¹£us:
I now establish the training rule for the bhiká¹£us, which should be recited like this:
If a bhiká¹£u eats food that has been touched by a non-relative, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
If a bhiká¹£u refers to the bhiká¹£u Kolita, the rest is as above.
Once touched means there are two kinds of touching:
1. Receiving before noon and touching after noon, 2. Receiving after noon and touching after the next noon.
If a bhiká¹£u knows it is food that has been touched by a non-relative, and he eats it without performing the proper procedure, he commits an offense as stated above.
What are the circumstances of this offense?ğŸ”½If a bhiká¹£u has the idea that food has been touched by a non-relative or has doubts about it, and he eats it, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
If it has not been touched by a non-relative, but he has the idea that it has or has doubts about it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If it is neither touched nor thought to be touched, or if it is touched but thought not to be touched, there is no offense.
The Buddha said:
If a bhiká¹£u has touched a bowl and has not washed it well, or if he uses a small bowl, spoon, copper cup, or salt container to drink or eat, he commits a pÄyattika offense.

If he touches a bowl bag, wiping cloth, staff, door lock, or other such objects, and then does not wash his hands, and then touches other food or even fruit, and swallows it, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
If a bhiká¹£u wants to drink water but does not rinse his mouth, and then swallows it, he commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
If he rinses his mouth with pure beans, earth, or other such things, there is no offense.
Moreover, there is no offense for a first-time offender, and the rest is as explained above.
The training rule on not receiving food, number thirty-nine. The Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time, the monk MahÄkoá¹£á¹­hila always used a bowl from a deep charnel ground, meaning a place where corpses are discarded, old name Å›Ä«tavana is a misspelling, and wore clothes from a deep charnel ground, ate food from a deep charnel ground, and used bedding from a deep charnel ground.
What is a bowl from a deep charnel ground?

What are clothes of the dead?
The relatives give clothes to the dead and abandon them in the fields. MahÄkoá¹£á¹­hila took them to wash, dye, and sew into clothes.
What is food of the dead?
The relatives would offer five lumps of food to the deceased spirits, and at that time, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila would take them to fill his stomach.
What is the bedding of a dead person?
This MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila always slept in the place of corpses.
These are the forest, bowl, food, and bedding of corpses.
If there were many deaths, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila's body would become plump and he would not go to the city to beg for food frequently.
If there were no deaths, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila's body would become emaciated and he would go to the city to beg for food frequently.
At that time, the gatekeeper thought in his mind:

If there are many deaths, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila's body becomes plump, and if there are few deaths, his body becomes emaciated. Could it be that the Venerable MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila eats the flesh of dead people?
At that time, in this city there was a brahmin who had just married and had a daughter. As the daughter grew up, her father passed away.
At that time, the relatives fully prepared the funeral rites, sent her to the charnel ground to be cremated, and returned home. Her wife and daughter cried to one side.
At that time, MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila was watching the cremation of the corpse. The daughter saw it and said to her mother:
Now this noble MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila is like a blind crow, guarding the corpse.
At that time, someone heard this and came to tell the bhiká¹£us. The bhiká¹£us informed the Buddha, and the Buddha said:

That brÄhmaá¹‡a girl has harmed my Å›rÄvaka disciples who are virtuous like Mount Sumeru. She has made coarse and evil words to insult them. Because of this evil karma, she will always be a blind crow for five hundred lifetimes.
At that time, people near and far all heard the World-Honored One's prediction that the brÄhmaá¹‡a girl would always be a blind crow for five hundred lifetimes.
Her mother heard this and said:
The Buddha has predicted that my daughter will always be a blind crow for five hundred lifetimes. What greater suffering could there be!
The mother then took her daughter to where the World-Honored One was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Please have compassion and forgive this little girl. Because she is ignorant, she did not speak with a malicious mind, but rather with a light heart. Please show mercy and let it go.
The World-Honored One said:
How could I curse her to suffer?
Because this girl spoke with a light heart and coarse words, she will fall into the animal realm. If she had spoken with a heavy malicious mind, she would have fallen into hell.
When the woman heard this, she left her seat.
At that time, the people in the city saw the gatekeeper say:

They discussed further:
How can we know if it's true or not?
Have one person pretend to be a dead person, and all of you carry him to the charnel ground.
So they sent one person to pretend to be a dead body. That person said:
Do you want him to eat my flesh?
The others said:
You don't need to worry, we will protect you.

Then he immediately pretended to be a dead person, smeared his whole body with turmeric oil, lay on a bed with five balls of food for the dead, and they carried him out of the city towards the charnel ground.

Eat me!

He replied:

The people said:

Having said this, they followed him and reported to the other monks.
When the monks heard this, they reported it in detail to the World-Honored One. Having heard it, the World-Honored One thought like this:
Because the monks did not accept the food, this fault arose. Therefore, I now order the monks to accept and eat it, so that others may know.
As instructed by the Buddha, they accepted and then ate.
The monks did not know how to accept it.
The Buddha said:
There are five ways to accept:
First, the body receiving the body;
Second, the body receiving the object;
Third, the object receiving the body;
Fourth, the object receiving the object;
Fifth, placing on the ground to receive.
What is meant by the body receiving the body?
It means when others hand it with their hands, one receives it with one's own hands.
What is meant by the body receiving the object?
It means when others hand it with their hands, one receives it with one's alms bowl.
What is meant by the object receiving the body?
It means when others hand it with their alms bowls, one receives it with one's own hands.
What is meant by the object receiving the object?
It means when others hand it with their alms bowls, one receives it with one's own alms bowl.

What are the five?

It means injuring with a fingernail.

It means that it is naturally withered and dried up, and is not suitable for planting.

It means that it is damaged by the beaks of birds.
The next five are easy to understand.

The laypeople let go first, with the bhiká¹£us behind. The Buddha said:

The previous was a new precept, and this is a subsequent allowance. It should be said like this:
If a bhiká¹£u takes food that has not been offered to him and puts it in his mouth to chew and swallow, except for water and tooth cleaners, he commits an offense entailing confession.
If a bhiká¹£u means the elder BhÄdra, the rest of the meaning is as above.

Food means the two sets of five.

If a bhiká¹£u takes food that has not been offered to him and has the thought that it has not been offered, or doubts it, there are two grave and two minor offenses. The last two are not offenses.

You all listen well!

In the past, in the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a pratyekabuddha named Ká¹£emaá¹…kara, who lived in an ancient hermitage outside the city, always followed by countless hundreds of thousands of myriads of heavenly beings.

The pratyekabuddha knew this and then thought:

Out of compassion, he then rose into the sky in front of them, manifesting great spiritual powers, emitting smoke and flames from above and flowing clear water from below, performing inconceivable feats to inspire faith.

When the ordinary beings saw the spiritual powers, they quickly repented, throwing themselves to the ground like a great tree falling, bowing from afar at the sage's feet, seeking forgiveness and confessing their wrongdoing, saying:
May the great field of merit quickly descend. Our ignorance has sunk us in the mud of evil deeds. Please bestow your compassion and extend your hand to save us.
Then the sage descended, and the yaká¹£a took the dead man's hand from his bowl and threw it outside. He told the people in the city:
It is not the renunciant who really eats human flesh. It was my evil mind that slandered him. I bow at his feet and apologize.

The yaká¹£a at that time is now Elder Brother. Because of maliciously slandering the pratyekabuddha and proclaiming his faults, he was reborn in hell. If one performs purely black karma, one will receive purely black retribution. If one performs black and white mixed karma, one will receive mixed retribution.
